text: 1. This is the truth. As from a blazing fire sparks, being like unto fire 1 , fly forth a thousandfold, thus are various beings brought forth from the Imperishable, my friend, and return thither also.

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 2. That heavenly Person is without body, he is both without and within, not produced, without breath and without mind, pure, higher than the high Imperishable 2 .

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 3. From him (when entering on creation) is born breath, mind, and all organs of sense, ether, air, light, water, and the earth, the support of all.

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 4. Fire (the sky) is his head, his eyes the sun and the moon, the quarters his ears, his speech the Vedas disclosed, the wind his breath, his heart the universe; from his feet came the earth; he is indeed the inner Self of all things 3 .

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 5. From him comes Agni (fire) 4 , the sun being the fuel; from the moon (Soma) comes rain (Par g anya); from the earth herbs; and man gives seed unto the woman. Thus many beings are begotten from the Person (purusha).

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 6. From him come the Ri k , the Sâman, the

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: [paragraph continues] Ya g ush, the Dîkshâ (initiatory rites), all sacrifices and offerings of animals, and the fees bestowed on priests, the year too, the sacrificer, and the worlds, in which the moon shines brightly and the sun.

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 7. From him the many Devas too are begotten, the Sâdhyas (genii), men, cattle, birds, the up and down breathings, rice and corn (for sacrifices), penance, faith, truth, abstinence, and law.

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 8. The seven senses (prâ n a) also spring from him, the seven lights (acts of sensation), the seven kinds of fuel (objects by which the senses are lighted), the seven sacrifices (results of sensation), these seven worlds (the places of the senses, the worlds determined by the senses) in which the senses move, which rest in the cave (of the heart), and are placed there seven and seven.

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 9. Hence come the seas and all the mountains, from him flow the rivers of every kind; hence come all herbs and the juice through which the inner Self subsists with the elements.

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 10. The Person is all this, sacrifice, penance, Brahman, the highest immortal; he who knows this hidden in the cave (of the heart), he, O friend, scatters the knot of ignorance here on earth.

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 34:1 Cf. B ri h. Âr. II, 1, 20.

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 34:2 The high Imperishable is here the creative, the higher the noncreative Brahman.

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 34:3 Called Vish n u and Virâ g by the commentators.

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 34:4 There are five fires, those of heaven, rain, earth, man, and woman. Comm.

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
